translation:
Most Illustrious and Excellent Sir,

In accordance with the orders and instructions of the Most Illustrious and Excellent Sir on the 1st of the current month, at 7 o’clock in the evening, I marched from the camp at Picada with 120 ranks of the 5th Corps of Cavalry of the National Guard under my command and 24 ranks of the squadron of Major Simas commanded by Lieutenant Demétrio and Ensign Claro; and proceeding embarked with the appropriate horses on the 3 barges, towed by two war barges, with their competent garrison and crew, I disembarked at Morretes at 11 o’clock at night, and forming the necessary divisions, at one hour in the early morning I marched toward the enemy’s positions, cutting with some difficulty through fields and marshes, leaving the enemy’s advanced guards to the rear; and at 5 o’clock in the early morning I ambushed my forces in a thicket, which was a quarter of a league from the estate called Demanda, where the enemy was located; and at 8 o’clock in the day I marched on the enemy, and being attacked, they were completely dispersed; captured from the rebels were the Commander of the Force, Major Duarte Martins Canabarro, brother of David Canabarro, being severely wounded by a cut on one arm, and Lieutenant Francisco Xavier, nephew of Bento Manuel Ribeiro, and ten soldiers; five soldiers and a sergeant of poor condition were killed on the field; more of our possession remained, 18 bridled horses, some armament and more than 80 tame horses, of which I chose fifty that I ordered to be placed on the islands, and sixty head of cattle that the barges were able to carry. Of the legality at Morretes, in good order, 230 infantry commanded by Major Francisco Félix da Fonseca, who had brought the steam barge “Liberal,” which it was not necessary for them to operate. All the forces under my command behaved with the usual energy and valor, as did the crews and garrisons of the aforementioned war vessels. I made my withdrawal with everything from Morretes between 8 and 9 o’clock at night, and arrived happily at the camp at Picada at 10 o’clock the same night.

God preserve Your Excellency.
Camp at Picada, April 3, 1839.

Most Illustrious and Excellent Sir Visconde de Castro, Brigadier and Commander of the Garrison of the Capital city of Porto Alegre.

Francisco Pedro de Abreu.
Interim Major Commander of the 5th Corps.
